questions.text: Match the following poison and site of action : (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A-1,B-2,C-3,D-4

 

The correct matches for the poisons and their primary sites of action, based on typical pharmacological effects, are:

 

Option A. Datura: Acts on the CNS (Central Nervous System) due to its content of tropane alkaloids which cause anticholinergic effects.

 

Option B. Nicotine: Primarily affects the cardiovascular system (CVS), influencing heart rate and blood pressure through its stimulant effects on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

 

Option C. Nitric Acid: Its primary contact effect is on the skin, causing severe burns upon exposure.

 

Option D. Nux Vomica: Contains strychnine, which affects the spinal cord (spine), leading to heightened reflex excitability and convulsions.

 

Educational objective :

 

  • A-1: Datura acts on the CNS.
  • B-2: Nicotine affects the CVS.
  • C-3: Nitric Acid affects the Skin.
  • D-4: Nux Vomica acts on the Spine.

questions.text: Which enzyme catalyzes the conversion of a compound into IP3 and DAG? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Phospholipase C

 

Explanation:

 

Phospholipase C (PLC) is the enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) in the cell membrane to generate two important second messengers: inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). This reaction occurs when a ligand binds to a receptor (either G-protein coupled or tyrosine kinase receptor) that activates PLC. Subsequently, IP3 diffuses to the endoplasmic reticulum where it triggers calcium release, while DAG remains in the membrane to activate protein kinase C.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Adenylyl cyclase: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP), not IP3 and DAG. It's activated by stimulatory G-proteins (Gs) after receptor binding and generates cAMP as a second messenger.
  • Option b. Guanylyl cyclase: This enzyme catalyzes the formation of cyclic GMP (cGMP) from GTP. It exists in both membrane-bound and soluble forms, with the latter activated by nitric oxide. It does not produce IP3 or DAG.
  • Option d. Phospholipase A: This enzyme cleaves fatty acids from the sn-2 position of membrane phospholipids, generating arachidonic acid and lysophospholipids. It's involved in the production of eicosanoids but not IP3 or DAG.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The phosphoinositide signaling pathway involves phospholipase C-mediated hydrolysis of PIP2 to generate two distinct second messengers (IP3 and DAG) that work in tandem to increase intracellular calcium and activate protein kinase C, coordinating comprehensive cellular responses.

choices.text: Lateral part of the medial femoral condyle
Medial part of the medial femoral condyle
Lateral part of the lateral femoral condyle
Medial part of the lateral femoral condyle

questions.text: Most common site of osteochondritis dissecans: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Lateral part of the medial femoral condyle

 

Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) most commonly affects the lateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle of the knee joint. This condition involves the separation of a segment of articular cartilage and subchondral bone from the underlying bone surface, typically due to repetitive trauma or compromised blood supply. The knee is the most commonly affected joint in the body, and is also the largest joint in our body. The pathology involves an area of avascular necrosis that may lead to fragmentation and separation of bone and cartilage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medial part of the medial femoral condyle - This is not the typical location for OCD. The condition preferentially affects the lateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle due to biomechanical stresses and vascular patterns. The medial aspect experiences different loading patterns.

 

Option C. Lateral part of the lateral femoral condyle - While OCD can occur here, it is less common than the lateral part of the medial femoral condyle. The lateral femoral condyle is subjected to different biomechanical forces during knee motion.

 

Option D. Medial part of the lateral femoral condyle - This is an uncommon location for OCD. The blood supply and stress patterns in this region differ from those at the classic location on the lateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Osteochondritis dissecans most commonly affects the lateral part of the medial femoral condyle of the knee, involving separation of articular cartilage and subchondral bone due to compromised vascularity or repetitive trauma.

choices.text: Inhibit the release of GABA and glycine

questions.text: A patient was injured with a rusted metal object. What is the mechanism of action of tetanus toxin in such cases?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibit the release of GABA and glycine

 

Tetanus toxin, also known as tetanospasmin, is produced by the bacterium Clostridium tetani. When a person is injured by rusted metal, this bacterium can enter the body and produce the toxin. Tetanospasmin specifically targets the nervous system by binding to receptors on motor nerve terminals and getting internalized. It then travels retrogradely to the central nervous system where it inhibits the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and glycine from inhibitory interneurons.

 

GABA and glycine normally function to inhibit motor neurons and prevent excessive muscle contraction. By blocking these neurotransmitters, tetanospasmin causes unopposed muscle contractions, leading to the characteristic muscle spasms and rigidity seen in tetanus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibit the release of Acetylcholine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not inhibit acetylcholine (Ach) release. Instead, botulinum toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum inhibits the release of acetylcholine, leading to muscle paralysis rather than muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Inhibit the release of epinephrine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not affect the release of epinephrine. Epinephrine release is primarily regulated by the adrenal glands and not significantly impacted by tetanospasmin.

 

Option D. Inhibit the release of norepinephrine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not inhibit the release of norepinephrine. Norepinephrine release is also regulated by different mechanisms and is not directly influenced by tetanospasmin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanus toxin (tetanospasmin) inhibits the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contractions and the characteristic spasms of tetanus.

questions.text: Which form of vitiligo is initially progressive and later becomes stable and non-progressive? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental

 

  • Segmental vitiligo is a type of vitiligo that follows a dermatome or nerve segment.

 

 

  • It usually starts in early childhood and presents with depigmented macules or patches that are confined to one side of the body, following the distribution of a dermatome.
  • Segmental vitiligo progresses rapidly within the first 1-2 years, reaching its full extent, after which it becomes stable and non-progressive.
  • This type does not cross the midline and remains confined to the initial segmental area, making it distinct from other forms of vitiligo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mixed: Mixed vitiligo involves both segmental and non-segmental vitiligo. Non-segmental vitiligo can continue to progress indefinitely, making this option incorrect for the description of a vitiligo type that becomes stable and non-progressive.

 

Option C. Acrofacial: Acrofacial vitiligo affects the distal parts of the body, such as the hands, feet, and face. This form of vitiligo can progress over time and does not become stable and non-progressive.

 

Option D. Focal: Focal vitiligo presents with one or a few isolated macules in a non-segmental distribution. Although it can remain localized, it does not specifically follow the pattern of being initially progressive and then becoming stable and non-progressive as segmental vitiligo does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segmental vitiligo is characterized by its initial rapid progression confined to a segmental area, followed by stabilization and lack of further progression, distinguishing it from other forms of vitiligo that can remain progressive.

questions.text: In a community, a new disease led to 60 cases occurring in a year. There were 12 deaths in the given year due to the same disease. Calculate the case fatality rate for this new disease. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20%

 

Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is calculated using the formula:

 

  • CFR 
  • In this case: CFR = (12/60) × 100 = 20%
  • CFR is a proportion (not a rate) where numerator is part of denominator
  • It indicates that out of 100 cases of this disease, 20 are likely to die

 

Educational Objective: 

 


 

It is a proportion (not a rate) that indicates the percentage of cases of a disease that result in death.

questions.text: Which of the following set of values suggest primary hypothyroidism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low T4; High TSH

 

Primary hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland itself is not producing enough thyroid hormones (T4 and T3). This deficiency in thyroid hormone production leads to a decrease in circulating T4 levels. The pituitary gland responds to low T4 levels by increasing the secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) in an attempt to stimulate the thyroid gland to produce more thyroid hormones.

 

Thus, in primary hypothyroidism, the typical laboratory findings are:

 

  • Low T4: Indicates underproduction of thyroid hormone by the thyroid gland.
  • High TSH: Indicates the pituitary gland's response to low thyroid hormone levels by secreting more TSH to stimulate the thyroid gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low T4; Low TSH: This pattern suggests secondary (or central) hypothyroidism, where the problem lies either in the pituitary gland (which produces TSH) or the hypothalamus (which produces TRH that stimulates TSH production). Both T4 and TSH are low because the pituitary gland is not secreting enough TSH to stimulate the thyroid gland.

 

Option C. High T4; High TSH: This pattern is indicative of central hyperthyroidism, where there is excessive production of TSH from the pituitary gland, leading to an overactive thyroid and high levels of T4.

 

Option D. High T4; Low TSH: This pattern suggests primary hyperthyroidism, where the thyroid gland is overactive and produces too much thyroid hormone, leading to high T4 levels. The pituitary gland responds by reducing TSH production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary hypothyroidism is characterized by low T4 levels and high TSH levels due to the thyroid gland's failure to produce sufficient thyroid hormones and the pituitary gland's compensatory increase in TSH secretion.

questions.text:
Which are the tumor markers for the ultrasound image shown below? (NEET PG 2024)

 

 

 

  1. CA 125
  2. LDH
  3. AFP
  4. hCG
  5. CA 19-9
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1,2,3,4,5


The ultrasound image shows an ovarian mass, and various tumor markers are used in the evaluation of ovarian tumors to help in diagnosis and management:

 

  1. CA 125: This is primarily used as a marker for epithelial ovarian cancer, especially serous cystadenocarcinoma. Elevated levels of CA 125 are often associated with advanced stages of the disease.
  2. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): This marker is associated with dysgerminoma, a type of germ cell tumor of the ovary. Elevated LDH levels can suggest the presence of this tumor.
  3. AFP (Alpha-Fetoprotein): AFP is a marker used for yolk sac tumors, which are rare but aggressive ovarian germ cell tumors.
  4. hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin): hCG is elevated in cases of non-gestational choriocarcinoma, which is another form of germ cell tumor.
  5. CA 19-9: This tumor marker is associated with mucinous cystadenocarcinoma, a type of ovarian epithelial tumor. It is also elevated in other gastrointestinal malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Different tumor markers, including CA 125, LDH, AFP, hCG, and CA 19-9, are utilized to assess ovarian masses and differentiate between various types of ovarian tumors.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who is a chronic alcoholic was presented with complaints of confusion, tingling sensation. His history revealed polished rice is his main diet. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beriberi

 

The patient described in the question is a chronic alcoholic and has a diet primarily consisting of polished rice. Both factors are significant because they contribute to a deficiency in vitamin B1 (thiamine). Alcohol inhibits the absorption of thiamine in the intestines, and polished rice, which has had its aleurone layer removed during processing, is devoid of thiamine.

 

Thiamine deficiency can lead to Beriberi, which has two forms:

 

  • Dry Beriberi: Characterized by symmetrical motor and sensory neuropathy, often with symptoms such as confusion, tingling, tenderness, and muscle cramps. The symptoms mentioned in the question, such as confusion and tingling, align with this form.
  • Wet Beriberi: This form is associated with high-output cardiac failure and edema, which is not highlighted in this patient's symptoms but is also a consequence of severe thiamine deficiency.

 

Given the patient’s symptoms and history, the correct diagnosis is Beriberi due to thiamine deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phrynoderma: This is a condition associated with vitamin A deficiency, leading to follicular hyperkeratosis. It is not related to the symptoms described in this patient.

 

Option C. Psoriasis: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition that causes rapid skin cell turnover, resulting in scaling on the skin’s surface. It is unrelated to the neurological symptoms and dietary history presented in the question.

 

Option D. Eczema: Eczema, or atopic dermatitis, is a condition that makes the skin red, inflamed, and itchy. It does not correlate with the patient’s symptoms of confusion and tingling, nor with thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic alcoholism and a diet primarily consisting of polished rice can lead to thiamine deficiency, resulting in Beriberi, which can manifest as either dry (neurological symptoms) or wet (cardiac symptoms) Beriberi.

choices.text: Can occur in association with diabetes
Associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon
The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal
Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding scleredema?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Associated with sclerodactyly or Raynaud’s phenomenon.

 

Sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s Phenomenon are associated with Scleroderma (NOT with scleredema).

 

Scleredema & Scleroderma are different diseases.

 

 

Scleredema is not associated with sclerodactyly, Raynaud’s phenomenon, nail fold capillary changes or serum autoantibodies.

 

Scleredema:

Synonyms - Scleredema adultorum of Buschke, Scleredema Diabeticorum.

 

  • Scleredema results in taut skin with noticeable symmetrical, diffuse progressive, non-pitting induration. This is because the dermis has expanded, mucin has been deposited, and the subcutaneous fat has been replaced by coarse collagen fibers.
  • It commonly presents with erythema and induration on the posterior neck and back, along with a peau d'orange appearance of the skin. Interestingly, the hands and feet remain unaffected.
  • The condition is characterized by a 3-4 times thicker dermis than usual, caused by dysfunctional fibroblasts leading to increased type 1 collagen synthesis, but without fibroblast proliferation.

 

The most prevalent type of this condition is associated with diabetes mellitus, and it is more commonly found in men compared to other forms that are more frequently seen in women. The accumulation of collagen is attributed to irreversible glycosylation of collagen and its resistance to degradation by collagenase.

 

 

  • Against an erythematous backdrop, the image depicts scleredema in a diabetic patient with firm, non-pitting edema with induration on the upper back, neck, and shoulders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Can occur in association with diabetes: True, as scleredema is commonly associated with diabetes, where the glycosylation of collagen contributes to the pathology.

 

Option C. The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal: True, reflecting the histological changes in scleredema, including mucin deposition and increased type 1 collagen synthesis.

 

Option D. Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen: True, these are characteristic cutaneous manifestations of scleredema, indicating the skin's texture and appearance changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Bolognia 4th edition, chapter 46, page no 870

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 59 page no 59.09 - 59.11.

Question Level – HARD

Question Id-7440 Unique Key-Q1728345

questions.text: Identify the level of amputation: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Below Knee

 

The correct answer is Below Knee amputation. In the provided image, the amputation level shows both the tibia and fibula bones, indicating that the amputation is below the knee. A below knee amputation preserves the knee joint, which is crucial for improved mobility and prosthetic fitting compared to an above knee amputation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Above Knee: In an above knee amputation, only the femur would be visible as the amputation occurs above the knee joint, which is not the case in the image provided.

 

Option C. Lis Franc: A Lis Franc amputation is a type of foot amputation that involves the tarsometatarsal joints.

 

Option D. Chopart: A Chopart amputation involves a disarticulation through the midfoot, specifically at the talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints. The image does not show the foot structures required for a Chopart amputation, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a below knee amputation, both the tibia and fibula bones are visible, distinguishing it from above knee and foot-level amputations like Lis Franc and Chopart.

questions.text: A person died suddenly whose family is abroad. A preservative was used to preserve his viscera. Which of the following poisoning is seen in it? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aconite

 

The question describes a scenario of sudden death where a preservative was used to preserve the viscera. The key point here is the suspicion of poisoning leading to sudden death. Aconite is a well-known cardiac poison that can cause sudden death by affecting the heart's function. Cardiac poisons such as aconite disrupt normal cardiac activity, leading to fatal arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol: While alcohol poisoning can be fatal, it typically does not cause sudden death in the manner described. The symptoms and progression of alcohol poisoning differ significantly from those of cardiac poisons.

 

Option B. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning usually presents with gastrointestinal symptoms and systemic toxicity. It is less likely to cause sudden cardiac death compared to aconite.

 

Option D. Thymol: Thymol is an antiseptic and fungicide, not typically associated with poisoning that leads to sudden death. Its toxic effects do not align with the scenario described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aconite is a potent cardiac poison known for causing sudden death due to its severe impact on cardiac function

 

Cardiac poisons: Mnemonic - DHONAQ

 

Digitalis, Hydrogen cyanide, Oleander, Nicotine, Aconite, and Quinine.

choices.text: Not given after 6 months of age
Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine

questions.text: All are true about Rotaviral vaccine except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Not given after 6 months of age

 

The Rotaviral vaccine is included in the National Immunization Schedule of India and is primarily available in two types: Rotavac and Rotasil.
 

 

Note -

 

  • The vaccine is typically given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age under NIS, with the possibility of extending the schedule up to 12 months in cases of delayed immunization.
  • Both vaccines are live attenuated, but VP8 subunit vaccine is also available, offering more strain specificity and showing good results in infants, adolescents, and adults.

 

However, it is incorrect to state that the vaccine is "Not given after 6 months of age," as it can be administered up to 12 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subunit vaccine: This statement is true as there is a subunit vaccine for rotavirus, specifically the VP8 subunit V protein vaccine, which has shown good results in various age groups.

 

Option C. Oral route of administration: This is correct. Rotaviral vaccines are given orally.

 

Option D. Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine: This is also correct. Rotavac is a monovalent vaccine, and Rotasil is a pentavalent vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rotaviral vaccine can be given up to 12 months of age according to the National Immunization Schedule of India.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a focal non-cicatricial cause of alopecia? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discoid Lupus Erythematosus

 

  • Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE) is a cicatricial (scarring) form of alopecia, not a non-cicatricial cause. 

 

 

  • DLE destroys hair follicles, leading to permanent hair loss with scarring. 
  • It's specifically classified under "Connective tissue diseases" in scarring alopecias. 
  • When DLE affects the scalp, it leads to inflammatory lesions that heal with scarring, resulting in irreversible hair loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alopecia Areata:

 

  • This is correctly classified as a non-cicatricial alopecia. 
  • It's characterized by circular patches of complete hair loss with exclamation mark hairs at the periphery. 

 

 

  • Hair follicles remain preserved, making it potentially reversible.

 

Option B. Secondary Syphilis:

 

  • Secondary syphilis can cause a moth-eaten, patchy pattern of hair loss, which is non-cicatricial. 

 

 

Option C. Black Dot Type Tinea Capitis:

 

  • This is a non-inflammatory type of tinea capitis where infected hairs break off at the scalp surface, leaving behind characteristic black dots.

 

 

  • It is non-cicatricial, as there is no permanent follicular damage. 
  • However, other inflammatory forms of tinea capitis like kerion (boggy inflammatory mass) and favus (yellow cup-shaped crusts) can destroy hair follicles and cause cicatricial alopecia if not treated early.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE) is a cause of focal cicatricial alopecia and thus is not classified among focal non-cicatricial causes of hair loss.

questions.text: Which contrast is used in PET scan? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) FDG

 

Positron Emission Tomography (PET) is an imaging technique used primarily in oncology, cardiology, and neurology. The contrast agent used in PET scans is 18F-FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose). FDG (a ligand) is a radiopharmaceutical composed of glucose molecules labeled with the positron-emitting isotope fluorine-18.

 

When injected into the body, FDG mimics glucose and is taken up by cells with high glucose metabolism, such as cancer cells. The Warburg effect, a phenomenon where cancer cells preferentially consume glucose for energy, makes FDG particularly useful in identifying tumors. The positrons emitted by fluorine-18 interact with electrons in the body, producing gamma rays that are detected by the PET scanner to create detailed images of metabolic activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iohexol: Iohexol is an iodinated contrast agent typically used in CT (Computed Tomography) scans, not PET scans. It does not emit positrons and is not used to highlight areas of high metabolic activity.

 

Option B. Calcium: Calcium is not used as a contrast agent in PET scans. While calcium can be a component of certain contrast agents used in other types of imaging like fluoroscopy, it has no role in PET imaging.

 

Option C. Gadolinium: Gadolinium is a contrast agent used in MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging). It helps enhance the contrast of images in MRI but does not work with the PET scanning process, which relies on positron emission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The contrast agent used in PET scans is 18F-FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose), which highlights areas of increased glucose metabolism, such as cancer cells.

questions.text: A patient with alkaline urine has the presence of the following type of urinary crystals. What is the likely composition of these crystals?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnesium ammonium phosphate

 

The presence of urinary crystals can help diagnose the type of stones a patient may be forming. The type of crystal seen in the urine is highly dependent on the urine pH:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite): These crystals are typically found in alkaline urine and have a characteristic "coffin lid" appearance. They are associated with infections by urease-producing bacteria and are also known as staghorn calculi due to their large, branching structure in the kidneys.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Calcium oxalate: These crystals are typically found in acidic to neutral urine and have an envelope or dumbbell shape. They are the most common type of kidney stones.

 

Option B. Uric acid: These crystals are found in acidic urine and often have a rosette or irregular shape.

 

Option C. Cystine: These crystals appear in acidic urine and have a hexagonal shape, associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate crystals, which appear as "coffin lid" shapes, are typically found in alkaline urine and are associated with struvite stones.

 

Urinary Crystals and pH Association:

questions.text: What does the Myenteric plexus in the gastrointestinal tract primarily control? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. GI motility

 

Explanation:


The Myenteric plexus (also known as Auerbach's plexus) is one of two major nerve plexuses in the enteric nervous system. It is located between the longitudinal and circular muscle layers of the gastrointestinal tract. This anatomical position allows it to directly influence the surrounding muscle layers, coordinating their contractions to produce peristalsis and other motility patterns essential for propelling food through the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. GI secretions - This is incorrect because secretion is primarily controlled by the Submucosal plexus (Meissner's plexus), not the Myenteric plexus.
  • Option b. Local blood flow - This is not the primary function of the Myenteric plexus.
  • Option d. All of the above - This is incorrect since the Myenteric plexus primarily controls motility, not all the listed functions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Myenteric plexus (Auerbach's plexus) is specialized for controlling GI tract motility, while the Submucosal plexus (Meissner's plexus) primarily regulates secretory functions.

questions.text: In which section of the mediastinum is the arch of the aorta located? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Superior mediastinum

 

Explanation:

 

The arch of the aorta is located in the superior mediastinum. The superior mediastinum lies above an imaginary plane passing through the sternal angle (manubriosternal junction) anteriorly and the lower border of the T4 vertebra posteriorly. This division separates the superior mediastinum from the inferior mediastinum. The arch of the aorta begins behind the upper border of the second right sternocostal joint, arches upwards, backwards, and to the left, and ends at the lower border of the T4 vertebra, forming a major structure within the superior mediastinum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior mediastinum: This is part of the inferior mediastinum, located behind the pericardium. It contains the descending thoracic aorta (not the arch), esophagus, thoracic duct, azygos and hemiazygos veins, and splanchnic nerves.

 

Option C. Middle mediastinum: This section of the inferior mediastinum contains the heart enclosed in the pericardium, the ascending aorta (not the arch), and the pulmonary trunk. The arch of the aorta lies above this division.

 

Option D. Anterior mediastinum: This is the smallest part of the inferior mediastinum, located between the sternum and the pericardium. It contains the thymus gland (or its remnants), lymph nodes, and areolar tissue. The arch of the aorta is not found here.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The arch of the aorta is a key structure in the superior mediastinum, along with the brachiocephalic veins, superior vena cava, trachea, and esophagus.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Confabulation
  2. Amnesia
  3. Peripheral neuropathy
  4. Ophthalmoplegia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder most commonly caused by severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). It is often associated with alcohol misuse, but can also be caused by other conditions. The primary features of Korsakoff syndrome include:

 

1. Confabulation: Patients often create false memories or stories to fill in gaps in their memory. These are not intentional lies, but rather attempts to make sense of their memory loss.

 

2. Amnesia: This involves significant memory impairment. Anterograde amnesia (difficulty forming new memories) is more prominent than retrograde amnesia (difficulty recalling past memories).

 

3. Peripheral neuropathy: This is also seen in Korsakoff syndrome, involving nerve damage that can cause pain, numbness, or weakness, typically in the hands and feet.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Ophthalmoplegia: This is not a feature of Korsakoff syndrome. Ophthalmoplegia, or paralysis of the eye muscles, is a characteristic of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which often precedes Korsakoff syndrome but is a separate condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and peripheral neuropathy, but not ophthalmoplegia, which is associated with Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with delayed periods and vaginal bleeding. An ultrasound reveals retained products of conception, and a suction evacuation is performed. The extracted tissue is sent for histopathology, which reports a karyotype of 46XX and is p57kip2 negative. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complete mole

 

The diagnosis is complete mole based on two key findings:

 

  1. Diploid karyotype (46XX) - Complete moles typically have a diploid karyotype
  2. p57kip2 negative staining - p57kip2 is a paternally imprinted, maternally expressed gene. Its negative expression is diagnostic of complete mole as there is no maternal genetic material

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Partial mole - Incorrect because:

 

  • Partial moles have triploid karyotype (69XXX or 69XXY)
  • p57kip2 is positive in partial moles due to presence of maternal genetic material

 

Option C. Invasive mole - Incorrect because:

 

  • This is a complication of molar pregnancy where the mole invades the myometrium
  • Diagnosis requires imaging evidence of myometrial invasion
  • Karyotype alone cannot diagnose invasive mole

 

Option D. Choriocarcinoma - Incorrect because:

 

  • This is a malignant form of gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Diagnosis is based on histopathology showing malignant trophoblastic tissue
  • Cannot be diagnosed by karyotype and p57kip2 staining alone

 

Educational Objective: 

 

complete molar pregnancy is characterized by:

 

  1. Diploid karyotype (46XX)
  2. Negative p57kip2 staining
  3. Complete absence of maternal genetic material

questions.text: In a patient after giving a Noradrenaline injection heart rate started to decrease, what is the reason for it: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stimulation of Baroreceptor

 

Explanation: 

 

When noradrenaline (a sympathetic agent) is administered, it activates the sympathetic system leading to an increase in blood pressure. This increased blood pressure activates baroreceptors, triggering a reflex response. Since noradrenaline has already bound to its receptors and cannot decrease blood pressure directly, the body activates the cardio inhibitory center (CIC) to inhibit the SA node. This inhibition leads to bradycardia, known as reflex bradycardia. This is a compensatory mechanism to help maintain blood pressure homeostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stimulation of alpha 2 receptors: Incorrect because heart does not have alpha 2 receptors. Alpha receptors are primarily involved in vasoconstriction.

 

Option C. Stimulation of beta 1 receptors: Incorrect because beta 1 receptor stimulation would cause an increase in heart rate (tachycardia), not a decrease.

 

Option D. Inhibition of Baroreceptor: Incorrect because inhibition of baroreceptors would lead to tachycardia, not bradycardia. Baroreceptor inhibition removes the "brake" on heart rate.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Baroreceptor stimulation due to increased blood pressure can cause reflex bradycardia as a compensatory mechanism, even when using sympathetic agents like noradrenaline.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient has just undergone surgery and requires a drug to reverse the muscle relaxation induced during the procedure. Which of the following drugs is used for this purpose? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neostigmine

 

Neostigmine is the correct answer because it is commonly used to reverse the muscle relaxation induced during surgeries. Neostigmine works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, an enzyme responsible for breaking down acetylcholine. By inhibiting this enzyme, neostigmine increases the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which counteracts the effects of muscle relaxants used during surgery.

 

In clinical practice, neostigmine is often administered alongside atropine. This combination is used to mitigate the cholinergic side effects (such as bradycardia) that can occur due to the increased acetylcholine levels. Atropine, an anticholinergic drug, helps prevent these unwanted side effects by blocking the action of acetylcholine on the heart and other tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bethanechol: Bethanechol is a cholinergic drug used primarily to treat urinary retention and is not used to reverse muscle relaxation induced during surgery.

 

Option B. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug and is used to prevent the side effects of neostigmine rather than to reverse muscle relaxation itself.

 

Option D. Edrophonium: Edrophonium is another acetylcholinesterase inhibitor but is generally used for diagnosing myasthenia gravis rather than reversing muscle relaxation in the surgical setting. Neostigmine is preferred in this context due to its longer duration of action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reversal agents:

 

  • Neostigmine is commonly used to reverse the effects of muscle relaxants after surgery. It works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, and is combined with atropine to prevent cholinergic side effects.
  • Sugammadex: Known as a Selective Relaxant Binding Agent (SRBA). Specifically used to reverse the effects of Rocuronium and Vecuronium. It is the fastest acting reversal agent and does not cause cholinergic side effects, eliminating the need for atropine.

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image.  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image shows a characteristic palisading arrangement of hyperchromatic (darkly stained) cells, which is indicative of basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

 

Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells of the epidermis. It is characterized by the presence of basaloid cells arranged in a palisading pattern, with peripheral cells exhibiting hyperchromatic nuclei and a paler center.

 

The key features that suggest this image represents basal cell carcinoma include:

 

  1. Palisading arrangement: The tumor cells are arranged in a distinct palisading pattern, with peripheral cells arranged in a radial fashion around the center.
  2. Hyperchromatic cells: The cells at the periphery of the tumor nests have darkly stained (hyperchromatic) nuclei, which is a characteristic feature of basal cell carcinoma.
  3. Lack of keratinization: Unlike squamous cell carcinoma, there is no evidence of keratinization (formation of keratin pearls) in this image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of skin cancer typically shows evidence of keratinization and does not exhibit the distinctive palisading pattern observed in the image.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: This is a type of cancer that originates from glandular epithelial cells and is not typically found in the skin.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma: This is a type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes and typically exhibits a different morphological appearance, with the presence of melanin pigment and atypical melanocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic palisading arrangement of hyperchromatic basaloid cells is a hallmark feature of basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells of the epidermis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy involved in drug abuse reports experiencing cross-over of sensory perceptions, where he describes that sounds can be seen and colors can be heard. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for this effect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. LSD

 

Explanation: 

 

The phenomenon described is synesthesia (reflex hallucinations), where stimulation in one sensory modality leads to experiences in another sensory modality (e.g., "seeing" sounds or "hearing" colors). This effect is most commonly associated with hallucinogens, particularly LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide).

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Cocaine (Incorrect): Cocaine is a stimulant that primarily causes sympathetic activation (tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis) and euphoria. While cocaine can cause psychotic symptoms like paranoia and tactile hallucinations ("cocaine bugs" or formication), it does not typically cause synesthesia or sensory crossover effects.
  • Option C. Marijuana (Incorrect): While cannabis (marijuana) can also cause synaesthesia or reflex hallucinations, between cannabis & LSD, LSD remains the better answer as these perceptual disturbances are the characteristic feature of hallucinogen intoxication.
  • Option D. PCP (Incorrect): Phencyclidine (PCP) is a dissociative anesthetic that can cause hallucinations, detachment from reality, and severe behavioral disturbances. While it can cause various perceptual disturbances, the specific cross-sensory phenomenon of synesthesia is more characteristic of classical hallucinogens like LSD.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Synesthesia (the crossing or merging of sensory modalities) is a characteristic effect of hallucinogenic drugs, particularly LSD. This perceptual phenomenon, where stimuli in one sensory domain trigger experiences in another (like seeing sounds or tasting colors), is part of the profound alterations in consciousness that make LSD and similar substances powerful hallucinogens.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases in inflammation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Albumin

 

During inflammation, various proteins called acute phase reactants change their serum concentrations. These reactants are divided into positive and negative acute phase reactants based on whether their levels increase or decrease in response to inflammation.

 

Negative acute phase reactants decrease during inflammation. These include:

 

(Mnemonic: RATT)

 

  • Retinol-binding protein (RBP): This protein also decreases during inflammation.
  • Albumin: Its levels decrease during acute and chronic inflammation as part of the body's response to redistribute amino acids for the production of positive acute phase proteins.
  • Transferrin: Its levels also decrease during inflammation.
  • Transthyretin (prealbumin): Another negative acute phase reactant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CRP (C-reactive protein): CRP is a positive acute phase reactant that increases during inflammation. It is commonly used as a marker to assess the presence and intensity of an inflammatory response.

 

Option B. Hepcidin: Hepcidin is another positive acute phase reactant that increases during inflammation. It plays a role in regulating iron metabolism.

 

Option D. Ferritin: Ferritin is a positive acute phase reactant that increases in response to inflammation. It serves as an indicator of body iron stores and also rises during inflammatory states.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Albumin is a negative acute phase reactant that decreases during inflammation, while CRP, hepcidin, and ferritin are positive acute phase reactants that increase.

questions.text: Which phenomenon is regulated by the asymmetrical distribution due to the Gibbs-Donnan effect? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Chloride Shift

 

Explanation:

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect describes the distribution of diffusible ions across a semipermeable membrane when one ion cannot diffuse through the membrane. The Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium establishes that in the presence of a non diffusible ion, diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal. This principle directly governs the chloride shift, where chloride ions move across red blood cell membranes to maintain electrical neutrality.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Bohr Effect: This refers to hemoglobin's decreased affinity for oxygen when carbon dioxide increases or pH decreases, not regulated by Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium.
  • Option C. Haldane Effect: This describes how oxygenation of blood decreases its ability to carry carbon dioxide, not regulated by Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium.
  • Option D. None of the above: Incorrect as chloride shift is regulated by Gibbs-Donnan effect.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect is fundamental to understanding ion distribution across semipermeable membranes, particularly explaining the chloride shift where chloride ions move into red blood cells as bicarbonate moves out.

questions.text: Cover-uncover test can be used in all conditions EXCEPT: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Visual acuity & Amblyopia

 

Explanation: 


The cover-uncover test is a clinical examination technique used to detect and assess strabismus (ocular misalignment). It is particularly useful for both manifest squint (tropia) and latent squint (phoria), as well as latent nystagmus. However, it has no role in assessing visual acuity or diagnosing amblyopia.

 

In the cover-uncover test, when examining a patient with tropia (manifest squint), first a cover test is performed where the normal eye is covered to observe if the squinting eye takes up fixation. Then, in the cover-uncover test, the cover is removed to observe the movement of the previously covered eye (secondary deviation).

 

For phoria (latent squint), the cover-uncover test is used to break fusion and reveal the hidden misalignment. When one eye is covered, fusion is disrupted, and upon uncovering, the eye movement can be observed as the eyes attempt to regain fusion.

 

In latent nystagmus, covering one eye can induce or intensify nystagmus, which can be observed when the cover is removed.



 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Latent nystagmus: Incorrect. The cover-uncover test is useful for diagnosing latent nystagmus. When one eye is covered in patients with latent nystagmus, the uncovered eye may exhibit nystagmus (eye dancing movement) that was not visible when both eyes were open. The test helps reveal this hidden nystagmus.

 

Option B. Latent squint: Incorrect. The cover-uncover test is specifically designed to detect latent squint (phoria). In phoria, both eyes appear straight when open, but when fusion is disrupted by covering one eye, the hidden misalignment is revealed. Upon uncovering, the eye movement that occurs to regain fusion can be observed.

 

Option C. Manifest squint: Incorrect. For manifest squint (tropia), the cover test is initially performed by covering the normal eye to observe if the squinting eye takes up fixation. Then, the cover-uncover test is used to assess the secondary deviation as the cover is removed from the normal eye. This helps differentiate between different types of tropias.

 

Educational Objective: 


The cover-uncover test is a clinical examination technique used to detect and assess strabismus (ocular misalignment) including manifest squint (tropia), latent squint (phoria), and latent nystagmus, but it has no role in assessing visual acuity or diagnosing amblyopia.

choices.text: Nernst potential for Cl– is –90 mV

questions.text: Which statement is true about the Nernst equation? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Used to calculate equilibrium potential

 

Explanation:


The Nernst equation is fundamentally used to calculate the equilibrium potential for individual ions across a cell membrane. The equation expresses the relationship between the equilibrium potential (E) of an ion and its concentration gradient across the membrane. This mathematical tool determines the membrane potential at which the electrical gradient exactly balances the concentration gradient for a specific ion, resulting in no net movement of that ion.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option b. Calculated for non-ionic solutions - The Nernst equation specifically applies to ions and ionic solutions, not non-ionic solutions. It calculates the potential difference created by concentration differences of specific charged particles.
  • Option c. Nernst potential for Cl– is –90 mV - This is incorrect. The equilibrium potential for Cl- in mammalian spinal neurons is approximately -70 mV, not -90 mV. The value of -90 mV is actually the equilibrium potential for K+ ions.
  • Option d. All are correct - This cannot be true as options b and c contain incorrect information.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Nernst equation is a fundamental tool in cell physiology that calculates the equilibrium potential for a specific ion across a membrane, representing the electrical potential at which diffusional and electrical forces acting on that ion are in balance.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was admitted to the hospital after three days of abdominal pain and vomiting. His laboratory reports revealed a potassium value of 3.2 mEq/L. All of the following can be seen except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cerebral edema

 

The patient has hypokalemia, indicated by a potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L.

 

This is not seen with Cerebral edema, which is typically associated with hyponatremia (low sodium levels) rather than hypokalemia. Hyponatremia can lead to an osmotic imbalance, causing water to move into brain cells and resulting in cerebral edema. This is not a recognized complication of hypokalemia.

 

Other options:

 

Hypokalemia can lead to several clinical manifestations:

 

Option A. Ventricular tachycardia: Hypokalemia can cause ventricular arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia, due to its effect on cardiac electrical activity. Potassium is crucial for maintaining normal heart rhythm, and its deficiency can lead to dangerous arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Quadriparesis: Hypokalemia can cause muscle weakness and paralysis, including quadriparesis. It affects muscle function because potassium is essential for normal muscle cell function and nerve transmission. Severe hypokalemia can mimic conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome.

 

Option C. Diabetes insipidus: Hypokalemia can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This condition occurs due to a defect in the kidney's ability to respond to antidiuretic hormone (ADH), leading to excessive urination and thirst. Hypokalemia impairs the kidney's concentrating ability, contributing to this disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral edema is not associated with hypokalemia; it is a complication of hyponatremia. Hypokalemia can cause ventricular arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is the most common used in day care surgery/TIVA?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propofol

 

Propofol is the most commonly used drug in daycare surgery and total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA). Daycare surgeries are short-duration procedures where the patient is admitted, operated on, and discharged on the same day.

 

TIVA refers to anesthesia that is both induced and maintained using intravenous agents, without the use of inhalational anesthetics. Propofol is ideal for these scenarios because it has a rapid onset and allows for a quick, clear-headed recovery after the procedure. It is known for inducing a state of unconsciousness that is described as "dreamless sleep," meaning that patients do not experience vivid dreams or nightmares during anesthesia. Furthermore, propofol has beneficial postoperative effects, including anti-emetic (preventing nausea and vomiting) and anti-pruritic (preventing itching) properties, which enhance patient comfort and satisfaction post-surgery. The drug is quickly metabolized, allowing patients to wake up promptly and with minimal residual effects, making it highly suitable for short-duration surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium thiopentone: While sodium thiopentone is a rapid-onset barbiturate that was once commonly used for induction of anesthesia, it is not preferred for TIVA or daycare surgeries because it has a longer half-life and can lead to a prolonged recovery period. Additionally, it lacks the anti-emetic and anti-pruritic properties of propofol.

 

Option C. Halothane: Halothane is an inhalational anesthetic agent and not used in TIVA, which relies solely on intravenous drugs. It is also associated with several side effects, including hepatotoxicity (liver toxicity), which makes it less ideal for daycare surgeries where quick recovery and minimal side effects are desirable.

 

Option D. Ketamine: Ketamine is an intravenous anesthetic that provides both anesthesia and analgesia. It is used in some cases for TIVA, especially in patients with cardiovascular instability because it does not depress the cardiovascular system. However, it can cause vivid dreams or hallucinations during recovery, making it less suitable for daycare surgeries where a smooth and clear-headed recovery is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is the drug of choice for day care surgeries and total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) due to its rapid onset, quick metabolism, and minimal postoperative side effects, including anti-emetic and anti-pruritic effects

questions.text: Which inhaled anesthetic agent is preferred for pediatric induction of anesthesia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhaled anesthetic agent for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients. This is primarily due to its pleasant, sweet smell, which makes it more tolerable for children to inhale. Additionally, Sevoflurane has a rapid onset of action, meaning it works quickly to induce anesthesia. This quick induction is critical in pediatric patients who often do not have an intravenous (IV) line placed before induction. The ability to induce anesthesia effectively and without distress is a significant advantage in this age group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is not preferred for pediatric induction because it has a pungent odor, which can be irritating and unpleasant for children. Moreover, it can cause airway irritation, which is undesirable during induction.

 

Option C. Isoflurane: While Isoflurane is effective as an anesthetic, it also has a pungent smell and slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane, making it less ideal for pediatric use.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane was previously used for pediatric induction, but it has largely fallen out of favor due to its potential for causing liver toxicity and its slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:


Sevoflurane is the anesthetic agent of choice for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its sweet smell and rapid onset of action.

questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on the EEG shown below: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM

 

The EEG provided shows a pattern that mimics an awake state, which is indicative of REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. REM sleep is characterized by specific EEG, EOG (electro-oculogram), and EMG (electromyogram) patterns:

 

  1. EEG (Electroencephalogram): During REM sleep, the EEG shows low amplitude, mixed frequency activity that resembles the awake state. This is in contrast to the high amplitude, low-frequency waves seen in NREM (Non-Rapid Eye Movement) sleep stages.
  2. EOG (Electro-oculogram): The EOG shows rapid eye movements, which are characteristic of REM sleep. These movements are visible as sharp spikes or fluctuations in the EOG tracing.
  3. EMG (Electromyogram): The EMG shows muscle atonia or paralysis, which is another hallmark of REM sleep. This paralysis prevents the sleeper from acting out their dreams. Only the diaphragm and extraocular muscles remain active during REM sleep.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NREM1: This is the lightest stage of sleep, characterized by a transition from wakefulness to sleep. The EEG shows a mix of alpha and theta waves, with some slow eye movements, but it does not resemble the awake state as closely as REM sleep does.

 

Option B. NREM2: This stage is marked by sleep spindles and K-complexes on the EEG. It is a deeper stage of sleep than NREM1 but does not show the rapid eye movements or muscle atonia seen in REM sleep.

 

Option C. NREM3: Also known as slow-wave sleep (SWS), this stage is characterized by high amplitude, low-frequency delta waves on the EEG. It is the deepest stage of NREM sleep and does not resemble the awake state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

REM sleep is characterized by EEG patterns similar to wakefulness, rapid eye movements on EOG, and muscle atonia on EMG.

questions.text: A patient with nasal bleeding was found to have nasal polyps; histopathology post-excision is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image features large sporangia containing numerous spores, typical of Rhinosporidiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinoscleroma: Caused by Klebsiella, characterized by Mikulicz cells, not seen here.

 

Option C. Hemangioma: Vascular tumor that would show proliferating blood vessels.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis: Fungal infection, but its histology typically shows spherules, not sporangia with spores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidiosis is characterized by its histopathology featuring large sporangia with spores, differentiating it from other nasal lesions such as Rhinoscleroma, Hemangioma, and Coccidioidomycosis.

questions.text: In a Holstein-Lewis fracture, which nerve is most commonly injured? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Radial

 

Holstein-Lewis fracture is a spiral fracture of the humerus at the junction of the middle and distal third, which is commonly associated with radial nerve injury. The radial nerve is particularly vulnerable at this location as it traverses the spiral groove of the humerus and comes to lie close to the bone at this junction. The injury to the nerve results in wrist drop due to paralysis of the wrist, finger and thumb extensors, the brachioradialis, and the supinator muscles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axillary - This nerve is commonly injured in shoulder dislocations and fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus, not in Holstein-Lewis fractures.

 

Option B. Median - This nerve can be injured in supracondylar fractures of the humerus but is not typically associated with Holstein-Lewis fractures. Median nerve injury would cause a "pointing index" deformity.

 

Option D. Ulnar - This nerve is commonly injured in fractures of the medial epicondyle or in elbow dislocations, not in spiral fractures of the humeral shaft. Ulnar nerve injury would result in a claw hand deformity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Holstein-Lewis fracture is a specific type of spiral fracture at the junction of middle and distal third of the humerus that has a high association with radial nerve injury resulting in wrist drop.

questions.text: A G3P2L1NND1 presents at 37 weeks with previous 2 LSCS with primary active HSV. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)


In a patient with a history of two previous lower segment cesarean sections (LSCS) and active primary herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at 37 weeks of gestation, an elective LSCS is the safest approach. Active HSV infection is a contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of neonatal herpes transmission, which can lead to severe complications in the newborn. A classical cesarean (vertical incision on the upper uterus) is not indicated here because the LSCS provides a safer and more appropriate route without the additional risks associated with classical cesareans, such as increased bleeding and uterine rupture in future pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Classical cesarean: A classical cesarean involves a vertical incision on the upper uterine segment and is generally reserved for cases where lower segment access is challenging, such as in preterm deliveries or certain uterine anomalies. It is not warranted here and would increase future obstetric risks.

 

Option C.  VBAC (Vaginal Birth After Cesarean): VBAC is contraindicated in this case due to active HSV infection and the risk of neonatal transmission. Additionally, VBAC is not recommended after two previous cesareans, especially when other complications like active infection are present.

 

Option D. IOL (Induction of Labor): Inducing labor is contraindicated in patients with active HSV due to the risk of viral transmission to the baby during delivery. This approach would pose significant risks without any benefit in this clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Active herpes simplex virus infection during labor is an indication for a cesarean section to prevent neonatal transmission.

questions.text: The corrected refractory error is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presbyopia

 

The "corrected" refractory error, which implies the condition after it has been corrected with appropriate lenses. Presbyopia is unique among the options as it's not a refractive error in the traditional sense, but an age-related condition affecting near vision. When corrected with reading glasses or multifocal lenses, presbyopia allows for clear near vision without altering distance vision, effectively "correcting" the inability to focus on near objects.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myopia: This is a refractive error where distant objects appear blurry. It's corrected with concave (minus) lenses, not the correction itself.

 

Option B. Hypermetropia (Hyperopia):  This condition causes difficulty focusing on near objects and is corrected with convex (plus) lenses, but it's not the corrected state.

 

Option D. Astigmatism:  This is an imperfection in the curvature of the eye's cornea or lens, corrected with cylindrical lenses, but again, it's not the corrected state itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presbyopia is unique among refractive conditions as its correction (typically with reading glasses) results in clear near vision without altering distance vision, effectively achieving a "corrected" state for both near and far vision

choices.text: It is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx.
It is associated with an omega-shaped epiglottis.
Stridor is increased on crying and relieved on lying prone.
Surgical Tracheostomy is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Laryngomalacia is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Surgical Tracheostomy is the treatment of choice.

 

Explanation:


Laryngomalacia is primarily managed conservatively, with observation being the mainstay of treatment. Tracheostomy is only required in select cases with severe respiratory obstruction, not as the first-line or treatment of choice. The condition typically resolves by 2 years of age as the laryngeal cartilages become more rigid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx: This is true. Laryngomalacia is indeed the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx.

 

Option B. It is associated with an omega-shaped epiglottis: This is true. Direct laryngoscopy findings include elongated epiglottis curled upon itself (omega-shaped Ω), floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

 

Option C. Stridor is increased on crying and relieved on lying prone: This is true. Stridor increases on crying but subsides when the child is placed in prone position. This clinical feature is characteristic of laryngomalacia and helps in its diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital laryngeal anomaly characterized by flaccid supraglottic structures causing inspiratory stridor that worsens with crying and improves in prone position; it typically resolves spontaneously by age 2 with conservative management being the mainstay of treatment, while tracheostomy is reserved only for severe cases.

choices.text: Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule

questions.text: Identify the correct match out of the following diuretics and the respective site of action: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule

 

Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors: These diuretics inhibit the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, which is located predominantly in the proximal convoluted tubule. This inhibition reduces the reabsorption of bicarbonate, sodium, and water in this segment, making "Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule" the correct match.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osmotic diuretics: These have a diffuse mechanism of action throughout the nephron, primarily affecting water-permeable regions such as the proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle. The statement "Osmotic diuretics → Collecting duct" is incorrect as the major sites of action are the proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb, not just the collecting duct.

 

Option C. Thiazides: Thiazide diuretics act on the distal convoluted tubule by inhibiting the sodium-chloride transporter. They do not primarily act on the Loop of Henle, making "Thiazides → Loop of Henle" incorrect.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonists: These drugs act on the collecting ducts, particularly affecting the principal cells where aldosterone promotes sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion. Therefore, the statement "Aldosterone antagonists → Distal Convoluted tubule" is incorrect as their primary site of action is the collecting duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diuretics with their site of action:

 

  • Osmotic diuretics → Proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle
  • Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule
  • Thiazides → Distal convoluted tubule
  • Aldosterone antagonists → Collecting duct

questions.text: A newborn baby came with complaints of hepatitis and cataract, lethargy & hypotonia. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely to be responsible for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase

 

The newborn presents with symptoms of hepatitis, cataract, lethargy, and hypotonia, which are indicative of a metabolic disorder involving galactose metabolism. The condition described here is galactosemia, specifically due to a deficiency in the enzyme Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).

 

Galactosemia is characterized by the inability to convert galactose into glucose. This metabolic block leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in various tissues, causing damage. The primary symptoms include:

 

  • Hepatitis: Liver damage due to the accumulation of toxic substances.
  • Cataract: Formation of oil drop cataracts in the lens of the eye due to galactose accumulation.
  • Lethargy and Hypotonia: Due to the overall metabolic derangement and hypoglycemia.

 

Metabolic pathway Galactose:

 

 

The key enzymes involved include Galactokinase and Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase. In classical galactosemia, the deficiency of the GALT enzyme leads to the clinical manifestations described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Galactokinase: Galactokinase deficiency leads to a milder form of galactosemia, primarily causing cataracts but not the full spectrum of symptoms like hepatitis and hypotonia seen in this case.

 

Option C. Uridyl glucuronyl transferase: This enzyme is related to bilirubin metabolism and is implicated in neonatal jaundice, not in the metabolism of galactose. Hence, its deficiency does not match the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactosemia due to Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency presents with hepatitis, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia, and is a contraindication for breastfeeding.

questions.text: All of the following Decreases GFR except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased Bowman Oncotic Pressure

 

The GFR is calculated using the formula: GFR = Kf × Net Filtration Pressure (NFP).

 

Net Filtration Pressure is determined by the balance between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures in the glomerular and Bowman's capsule. 

 

The Net Filtration Pressure (NFP) is calculated using the formula: NFP = (HPG - OPG) - (HPB - OPB) Where:

 

  • HPG = Hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries (pushing force, ~60 mmHg)
  • OPG = Oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries (pulling force, ~32 mmHg)
  • HPB = Hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's capsule (opposing force, ~18 mmHg)
  • OPB = Oncotic pressure in Bowman's capsule (normally negligible, ~0 mmHg)

 

Normally, NFP = (60-32) - (18-0) = 10 mmHg

 

When Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases, it pulls more water molecules from the glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's space. This increases filtration, resulting in increased GFR. Proteins in Bowman's capsule would pull more water molecules towards them, which constitutes the filtration process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased glomerular coefficient Kf: Incorrect because a decrease in Kf directly reduces GFR according to the formula GFR = Kf × NFP. The glomerular coefficient represents the permeability of the filtration membrane and its surface area.

 

Option B. Increase glomerular oncotic pressure: Incorrect because glomerular oncotic pressure is a pulling force that opposes filtration. When oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries increases, it holds water within the capillaries, reducing the amount of filtrate formed, thereby decreasing GFR.

 

Option C. Reduced Glomerular Hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect because glomerular hydrostatic pressure is the primary driving force for filtration. A reduction in this pressure means less force is available to push water and solutes across the filtration membrane, resulting in decreased GFR.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases, it pulls more water molecules from the glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's space. This increases filtration, resulting in increased GFR. Proteins in Bowman's capsule would pull more water molecules towards them, which constitutes the filtration process.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, cardiomegaly observed on imaging, pedal edema, a gallop rhythm on cardiac auscultation, and rales in both lungs. Based on this clinical presentation, which suggests congestive heart failure (CHF), which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to prevent the progression of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Captopril

 

The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with heart failure, as indicated by symptoms such as dyspnea on exertion, nocturnal dyspnea, cardiomegaly, pedal edema, a gallop rhythm, and rales in the lungs. All the listed drugs can be used in the management of heart failure, but the question specifically asks about preventing the progression of the disease.

 

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor, which has been shown to be effective in reducing mortality and morbidity in patients with heart failure and in preventing the progression of heart failure. It works by decreasing afterload and preload, improving symptoms, and slowing the progression of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that is used to reduce the symptoms of fluid overload in heart failure, such as pedal edema and pulmonary congestion, but it does not have a significant impact on the progression of the disease.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that can improve symptoms and cardiac function in heart failure but has not been shown to prevent the progression of the disease and is associated with significant toxicity.

 

Option D. Carvedilol: Carvedilol is a beta-blocker that has been shown to improve survival in heart failure. However, it is generally not used as a first-line therapy for acute exacerbation due to its initial negative inotropic effect, but it can be beneficial over the long term for improving cardiac function and reducing the risk of progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, is the best choice for preventing the progression of heart failure due to its effectiveness in reducing mortality and morbidity, decreasing afterload and preload, and improving symptoms and long-term outcomes in heart failure patients.

questions.text: The fabella is a sesamoid bone embedded in the tendon of?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Gastrocnemius

 

Explanation: 

 

The fabella is a sesamoid bone that is embedded specifically in the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle. It is located in the posterior aspect of the knee joint where the lateral head of gastrocnemius originates. Sesamoid bones develop within tendons where they cross joint surfaces or bony prominences, and the fabella develops in the posterolateral aspect of the knee within the gastrocnemius tendon.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Quadriceps - This is incorrect because the quadriceps tendon contains the patella as its sesamoid bone, not the fabella. The patella is the largest sesamoid bone in the body.

C. Flexor carpi ulnaris - This is incorrect because the flexor carpi ulnaris tendon may contain a sesamoid bone (the pisiform) in the wrist, not the fabella which is located at the knee.

D. Popliteus - This is incorrect because the popliteus muscle does not contain any sesamoid bone. The popliteus is a triangular muscle located in the posterior knee region but does not contain the fabella.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The fabella is a small sesamoid bone found within the tendon of the lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle at the posterior aspect of the knee joint.

questions.text: In which of the following transplantations is organ/body size comparison believed to be least important? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pancreas

 

Explanation:

 

Organ size matching is specifically mentioned as important for heart, lung, liver and small bowel transplantation, but not for pancreas transplantation. Allocation of organs must take into account the relative size of the donor and recipient for most organ types. While kidney transplants can be performed between adults and children without significant size concerns, the heart, lung, liver, and small bowel require more careful size matching. The pancreas doesn't appear in discussions of organs requiring strict size compatibility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heart - Incorrect. Size compatibility is critically important for heart transplantation. A heart that is too large won't fit in the recipient's chest cavity, while one that's too small may not provide adequate cardiac output for the recipient's body size. Precise size matching is essential for proper cardiac function.

 

Option B. Liver - Incorrect. Size matching is crucial for liver transplantation. An adult donor liver cannot be transplanted into a child because of the size mismatch. This has led to the development of split-liver transplantation, where the liver is divided so the left lobe or left lateral segments can be used for a child and the right lobe for an adult recipient.

 

Option D. Lung - Incorrect. Lung transplantation requires careful size matching to ensure proper fit within the chest cavity. Lungs that are too large cannot physically fit in the recipient's thoracic space, while lungs that are too small may not provide adequate respiratory function for the recipient.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While size matching is critical for heart, lung, liver, and small bowel transplantation, it is comparatively less critical for pancreatic transplantation among the given options.

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ulnar nerve

 

  • To monitor adequacy of neuromuscular blockade ulnar nerve is preferred.
  • It is monitored using a Train of Four monitor/peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle is seen on electrical stimulation of the ulnar nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve is frequently used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade during and after anesthesia.
  • It is typically monitored using a device known as a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • The ulnar nerve is accessible and provides a reliable location for monitoring. Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle (a muscle in the thumb) is commonly observed when electrical stimulation is applied to the ulnar nerve.
  • This twitch response is used to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade and the patient's recovery from anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median nerve: While the median nerve can be used for neuromuscular monitoring, the ulnar nerve is more commonly preferred because of its accessibility and ease of stimulation. The adductor pollicis muscle twitch response is typically more reliable for assessing neuromuscular blockade compared to other muscles.

 

Option C. Radial nerve: The radial nerve can also be used for neuromuscular monitoring, but it is not as commonly chosen as the ulnar nerve. Similar to the median nerve, the ulnar nerve offers a more reliable and standard location for monitoring.

 

Option D. Metacarpal nerve: There is no specific nerve called the "metacarpal nerve" commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade, typically assessed using a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.

questions.text: What is the function of the popliteus muscle? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Unlocking of knee joint

 

Explanation:

 

The popliteus muscle plays a crucial role in unlocking the knee joint. When the knee is in full extension, the femur undergoes Medial rotation in relation to the tibia (known as the "screw-home mechanism"), which locks the knee joint in place for stability during standing. The popliteus muscle initiates knee flexion by first rotating the femur laterally to unlock this mechanism. This unlocking action is essential before the hamstring muscles can effectively flex the knee joint. The popliteus is a triangular muscle located in the posterior aspect of the knee.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Locking of knee joint - This is incorrect. The locking mechanism of the knee is primarily a passive mechanism involving the medial rotation of the femur on the tibia in full extension, not an active muscular function of the popliteus. The quadriceps muscle group is responsible for extending the knee and contributing to the locking mechanism.

 

Option C. Medial rotation of femur on tibia - Popliteus rotates femur laterally and not medially

 

Option D. None of the above - This is incorrect as option B accurately describes the primary function of the popliteus muscle.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The popliteus muscle is essential for initiating knee flexion by unlocking the knee joint through lateral rotation of the femur on the tibia, reversing the "screw-home mechanism" that locks the knee in full extension.

choices.text: Increased by decreased renal blood flow

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Increased in hypoproteinemia

 

Explanation:


In hypoproteinemia, the concentration of plasma proteins, particularly albumin, is decreased. This reduction leads to a decrease in plasma oncotic pressure (πGC), which normally opposes filtration across the glomerular membrane. The glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is determined by the equation GFR = Kf × NFP, where NFP represents net filtration pressure. When oncotic pressure decreases, the net filtration pressure increases, resulting in greater filtration and thus higher GFR. This relationship is a direct application of Starling forces in the glomerular capillaries.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Increased by afferent arteriole constriction - This is incorrect because afferent arteriole constriction reduces blood flow to the glomerulus, decreasing glomerular hydrostatic pressure. Afferent arteriole constriction causes marked decrease in both renal plasma flow (RPF) and GFR.
  • Option b. Increased by decreased renal blood flow - This is incorrect because GFR is directly dependent on renal blood flow. When renal blood flow decreases, less plasma is available for filtration, resulting in decreased GFR. While GFR varies less than RPF, it still follows the same directional change.
  • Option c. Increased in hypotension - This is incorrect because hypotension (low blood pressure) reduces the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries (PGC). When mean systemic arterial pressure drops below the autoregulatory range, GFR drops sharply.
