Educational Objective:

 

GFR increases in hypoproteinemia because the reduction in plasma protein concentration decreases the oncotic pressure opposing filtration, thereby increasing the net filtration pressure across the glomerular membrane.

questions.text: What forms the lateral border of the cubital fossa? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a) Brachioradialis

 

Explanation:

 

The lateral border of the cubital fossa is formed by the medial border of the brachioradialis muscle. The cubital fossa is a triangular depression located at the anterior aspect of the elbow joint. Its boundaries are well-defined, with the brachioradialis forming the lateral boundary as this muscle courses from its origin at the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus downward toward the styloid process of the radius. This muscle is easily palpable when the forearm is flexed against resistance in the mid-prone position.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pronator teres: This muscle forms the medial boundary of the cubital fossa, not the lateral boundary. It runs from the medial epicondyle of the humerus to the middle of the lateral aspect of the radius.

 

Option C. Flexor carpi radialis: While located in the anterior compartment of the forearm, it does not form any boundary of the cubital fossa. It lies medial to the pronator teres.

 

Option D. Triceps: This is a posterior compartment muscle of the arm that inserts into the olecranon process of the ulna. It is not related to the boundaries of the cubital fossa, which is an anterior structure.

 

Education Objective: 

 

The cubital fossa is bounded laterally by brachioradialis, medially by pronator teres, with its apex formed by the meeting of these two muscles, and its base represented by an imaginary line connecting the humeral epicondyles.

questions.text: Reason of Hepatomegaly in Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of glycogen

 

The reason for hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) in this disease is the accumulation of glycogen. Glucose-6-phosphatase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. When there is a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, the normal breakdown of glycogen into glucose is impaired, leading to the accumulation of glycogen within the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Accumulation of Glucose-6-phosphate: While glucose-6-phosphate is an intermediate in glycogenolysis, its accumulation is not the primary cause of hepatomegaly in glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency. Increased Glu-6-P however causes other C/f such as Hyperuricemia, hypertriglyceridemia and Lactic acidosis.

 

Option C. Accumulation of Glucose-1-phosphate: Glucose-1-phosphate is an intermediate in glycogenolysis. It does not accumulate in Von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option D. Accumulation of glycogenin: Glycogenin is a protein that plays a role in initiating glycogen synthesis, not breakdown. Accumulation of glycogenin is not a typical feature of glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is known as Von Gierke’s disease or Type I GSD.

questions.text: Identify the structure indicated by the arrow:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory bronchus

 

 

 

The image shows a histological section of the lung with an arrow indicating a structure involved in gas exchange. The key features to identify include the presence of air spaces and the type of epithelium lining these spaces.

 

  • Respiratory Bronchus: This structure is part of the respiratory zone of the lung, where gas exchange occurs. It is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium transitioning to simple squamous epithelium as it progresses into the alveolar ducts and sacs. The respiratory bronchus is characterized by the presence of alveoli arising from its walls, indicating the start of the gas exchange process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar sac: Alveolar sacs are the terminal ends of the respiratory tree where clusters of alveoli are found. They are not the initial structures for gas exchange but are rather the sites where the alveoli are grouped.

 

Option C. Terminal bronchiole: Terminal bronchioles are the last part of the conducting zone and do not participate in gas exchange. They are lined with simple cuboidal epithelium without the presence of alveoli in their walls.

 

Option D. Intrapulmonary bronchiole: Intrapulmonary bronchioles refer to the bronchioles within the lung tissue that are part of the conducting zone and do not participate directly in gas exchange.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The respiratory bronchus is the structure where gas exchange begins in the lung, identified by its simple cuboidal epithelium and the presence of alveoli arising from its walls.

questions.text: An individual experiences intense fear and anxiety when confronted with tall structures and the prospect of looking down from great heights. Which term best describes this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acrophobia

 

Acrophobia is the fear of heights. This condition causes individuals to experience intense fear and anxiety when they are at a significant height or even when they think about being in such a situation. This fear can be triggered by standing on a tall structure or looking down from a height, and it often leads to avoidance of high places.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nomophobia: This is the fear of being without a mobile phone or losing signal on a mobile device.

 

Option C. Claustrophobia: This refers to the fear of confined or closed spaces, such as elevators or tight rooms.

 

Option D. Agoraphobia: This is the fear of places or situations where escape might be difficult, such as crowded places or open spaces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acrophobia is the term used to describe the fear of heights, a common phobia that can cause significant distress and avoidance behavior in individuals.
